stories.headline: HEGSETH OKS ARMING GUARD TROOPS IN D.C.
stories.summary: National Guard members participating in military deployment in Washington, D.C. have been authorized to carry firearms following approval from Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth. This move allows Guard members to provide enhanced security amid ongoing responsibilities.

stories.headline: Terror and confusion leave Villanova reeling
stories.summary: Following a false active shooter report at Villanova University, students experienced chaos and interruptions during their campus orientation. Officials are investigating the origins of the false report and working to restore normalcy while addressing the emotional impact on students and faculty.

stories.headline: Judge overturns murder conviction of Philadelphia man
stories.summary: A judge has overturned the murder conviction of Tyree Musier, a North Philadelphia man, after prosecutors found a key witness had lied. Musier, who has been incarcerated for nearly 20 years, now awaits a new trial, reflecting concerns over potential wrongful conviction.

stories.headline: Democrats could use SEPTA cuts to fuel state Senate flip
stories.summary: With upcoming SEPTA service cuts sparking public debate, Democrats see an opportunity to leverage transit issues to flip the state Senate in Southeastern Pennsylvania. State Rep. Malcolm Kenyatta hopes stranded transit riders will recognize who is responsible during the midterm elections.

stories.headline: Vanir rep: Firm leads prison project under DOC direction
stories.summary: A project director representing Vanir, a new prison builder in Franklin County, addressed recent communications about Vanir's role in prison construction under Department of Corrections direction. The spokesperson highlighted active involvement and positive progress, but noted that decisions depend on DOC leadership.

stories.headline: Hopes of lower rates fuel surge for Wall Street
stories.summary: Wall Street rallied to its best day in months following Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks hinting at possible interest rate cuts. The S&P 500 gained 1.5% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 846 points, fueled by optimism that lower rates would support economic growth and investment.

stories.headline: Powell hints Fed may cut interest rates soon
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell opened the door to potentially cutting interest rates but gave no clear hint on timing, urging caution as inflation risks remain high. Powell emphasized the Fed's careful monitoring of the economy and noted the uncertainty around future decisions as economic conditions evolve.

stories.headline: Israeli minister warns leveling city on table
stories.summary: Israel's defense minister warned that Gaza's largest city could be destroyed if Hamas does not comply with Israeli conditions for ending the conflict. The statement followed ongoing hostilities and dialogue about ceasefire terms, underscoring the high stakes in the region's conflict and humanitarian concerns.

stories.headline: Alligator Alcatraz's shutdown ordered
stories.summary: A federal judge has ordered the shutdown of the 'Alligator Alcatraz' detention center in Florida after ruling it was built on sensitive wetlands and used by environmentalists and outdoor people. The order requires the facility to wind down operations over two months following a legal challenge related to environmental concerns.

stories.headline: Final tuneup before season kicks off
stories.summary: Dallas Cowboys quarterback Joe Milton and running back Deuce Vaughn warmed up ahead of the final preseason game against the Atlanta Falcons in Arlington. The game is expected to be a competition for the backup quarterback spot behind Dak Prescott, drawing attention from fans and sports commentators.

stories.headline: Famine torments Gaza City
stories.summary: The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) has declared a famine in Gaza City, the world's largest city under siege due to the ongoing Israel-Hamas war. Food shortages threaten hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, with famine expected to spread to surrounding areas by next month. The IPC's declaration comes amidst warnings of increasing restrictions on food and other aid and calls for heightened international pressure on Israel to ease the humanitarian crisis.

stories.headline: García set for new chief gig
stories.summary: Eddie García, former Dallas police chief, was introduced as the next chief of the Fort Worth Police Department. García, who had left North Texas last year, returns to North Texas less than a year after retiring from the Dallas chief post. He vowed to lead the Fort Worth department with integrity and accountability, aiming to be a hands-on leader focused on police safety and serving the community.

stories.headline: Bolton’s home searched
stories.summary: The FBI searched the Maryland home and Washington office of John Bolton, former national security advisor under President Donald Trump's administration, as part of an investigation into the handling of classified information. Multiple media outlets reported the search. Bolton was not detained or charged with any crimes. Agents were seen taking bags into the office building through a back entrance during the search.

stories.headline: Senator vows filibuster after new maps get nod
stories.summary: The Texas Senate gave preliminary approval to a redistricting plan that could be critical for Republicans to maintain control of Congress in the 2026 midterm elections. The bill’s initial passage on an 18-11 party line vote came as a Houston Democratic state senator said she will attempt a filibuster to delay final passage of the plan. Republicans think they can walk all over us, but the senator vowed to kick back and fight the new congressional maps.

stories.headline: Neighbors split by redrawn lines
stories.summary: When Ann Zimmerman Gallant learned of a congressional redistricting map Texas Republicans introduced last month, she immediately looked to see how lawmakers had changed the district she lives in. Zimmerman Gallant lives in a North Dallas neighborhood sandwiched between Preston Hollow and Lake Highlands. She voted for U.S. Rep. Julie Johnson, D-Dallas, in the 2024 election. But looking at the new map, the former journalist noticed Johnson's 32nd congressional district would extend out to East Texas—near the Louisiana state line. It was a drastic revision of Johnson's district.

stories.headline: Fed probe targets Kilpatrick crony, $2.75M mansion
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors are investigating a $2.75 million mansion in Novi linked to former Detroit Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick amid allegations of bank and wire fraud. The probe includes a detailed look into a $6.58 million real estate deal and other financial crimes involving Kilpatrick and his associates. The investigation is part of a broader inquiry into fraud and money laundering connected to Kilpatrick, who was previously convicted and sentenced for corruption-related offenses.

stories.headline: Maxwell did not see Trump act in 'inappropriate way'
stories.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, imprisoned for her role in Jeffrey Epstein's sexual trafficking case, has repeatedly denied any sexual impropriety involving Donald Trump during questioning. The Trump administration released documents aiming to clear the former president of misconduct allegations, citing testimonies that show no inappropriate actions by Trump towards Maxwell. The case remains under scrutiny as political tensions around the issue continue.

stories.headline: Cuts to MSU's SNAP-Ed program to be felt statewide
stories.summary: Michigan State University's SNAP-Ed nutrition program faces significant staff layoffs after the federal government cut $10.5 million in grants. The program, which promotes healthy eating and active lifestyles for low-income families, is supported by partnerships with community groups and the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services. The reduction affects over 90 staff members and impacts nutrition outreach efforts in schools, rehabilitation centers, and senior living facilities across the state.

stories.headline: Ex sought in fatal shooting at Henry Ford Hospital
stories.summary: Mario Green, a 53-year-old man with a history of aggravated stalking and arson, is sought by police after fatally shooting his ex-wife at Henry Ford Hospital. Police said Green eluded metal detectors and fled the scene with a handgun after a confrontation with his ex-wife, who was an employee at the hospital. Authorities are actively searching for him and have issued warnings that he is armed and dangerous.

stories.headline: Blast probe could be curbed
stories.summary: The federal safety agency investigating the deadly Clairton Coke Works explosion is on President Donald Trump's chopping block, as the White House seeks to eliminate the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. The administration's 2026 budget proposal suggests duplicating the agency's capabilities with other federal bodies, potentially ending independent investigations into industrial chemical accidents, which has raised concerns about safety standards and environmental protections.

stories.headline: Bolton subject of FBI search
stories.summary: The FBI searched the Maryland home and Washington office of former Trump national security adviser John Bolton as part of a criminal investigation into the mishandling of classified information. Bolton, a known critic of President Trump, is reportedly under investigation amid political tensions between Trump supporters and opponents within the administration.

stories.headline: Lured by Pa. tax break, Shell mulls sale of plant
stories.summary: Shell is considering selling its ethane cracker plant in Beaver County, Pennsylvania, which was developed as part of an energy renaissance fueled by shale gas. The Department of Energy predicted the plant was strategically important; however, Shell cites challenges in the facility's operations and the local market. The outcome will impact local economic development and energy production.

stories.headline: Shapiro joins abortion medication fight
stories.summary: Governor Josh Shapiro has joined other states in opposing FDA restrictions on abortion medication. Shapiro and like-minded attorneys argue the limitations undermine safe access to abortion medications despite years of safe use. The move aligns with Shapiro's support for abortion rights amid ongoing national legal challenges.

stories.headline: MAXWELL DEFENDS TRUMP'S CONDUCT
stories.summary: Jeffrey Epstein's imprisoned former girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell denied to the Justice Department any sexually inappropriate interactions with Donald Trump. The Trump administration has released transcripts of interviews with Maxwell attempting to distance the president from Epstein-related allegations, despite ongoing controversy over Trump’s conduct and handling of evidence related to the case.

stories.headline: Baby’s parents arrested
stories.summary: The parents of 7-month-old Emmanuel Haro were arrested on suspicion of murder following his disappearance. Authorities have also conducted a search of their home as the investigation into the infant's disappearance continues. The case has raised serious concerns and is being closely followed by law enforcement and the community.

stories.headline: When Newsom tweets just like Trump, Fox News hosts go nuts
stories.summary: Fox News hosts criticized California Governor Gavin Newsom for mimicking former President Donald Trump's style of confrontational tweets. They portrayed Newsom's tone as childish and confrontational, drawing attention to the increasing politicization of social media communications and its impact on public discourse. The segment highlighted division in media coverage and political rhetoric.

stories.headline: This long-journeying bird connects two lakes — and communities
stories.summary: Wilson’s phalarope, a bird species that breeds in California's Mono Lake and migrates to Lagoa Mar Chiquita in Argentina, symbolizes a natural connection between the two communities. This small bird's impressive migration highlights the ecological and cultural ties between these distant regions, underscoring the importance of conserving migratory birds and their habitats.

stories.headline: Oklahoma to vet teachers on 'leftism'
stories.summary: Oklahoma plans to require teachers from states like California and New York to take an exam designed to guard against teaching 'radical leftist ideology.' The test, developed by the Oklahoma State Department of Education and advocacy groups, aims to ensure teachers in Oklahoma uphold certain conservative perspectives, sparking debate on education policy and political influence in schools.

stories.headline: Famine is formally declared in Gaza
stories.summary: After nearly two years of war, the Gaza Strip has officially been declared in a state of famine due to widespread hunger and a food crisis worsened by blockades and restricted access to essentials. This marks the first famine declaration in the Middle East, impacting millions of Palestinians amid ongoing conflict and humanitarian challenges.

stories.headline: 2nd Menendez brother faces parole board
stories.summary: Lyle Menendez appeared before the California Board of Parole to face questions about his credibility, prison rule violations, and alleged incidents of manipulation. The hearing follows the denial of parole to his brother Erik and discussed their involvement in the killing of their parents in 1989. The process included scrutiny by relatives and raised questions about potential parole.

stories.headline: Southland remains set on 'broil'
stories.summary: Southern California faces oppressive heat with advisories extended through Sunday as temperatures are expected to break records due to a heat wave. Experts warn that the extreme heat poses risks including potential wildfires and dangerous conditions, urging residents to prepare for continued high temperatures and heat warnings.

stories.headline: Abrego freed, but ICE seeks to deport him to Uganda
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego García was recently deported to El Salvador after being detained for human smuggling charges; however, ICE seeks to deport him further to Uganda, sparking discussions about immigration law enforcement and international deportation policies.

stories.headline: Bolton targeted in FBI searches
stories.summary: The FBI conducted searches on former Trump adviser John Bolton's Washington-area home and office investigating the possible illegal possession or sharing of classified information, raising concerns about long-standing accusations and handling of sensitive government materials.

stories.headline: Under tightening federal grip, officers say their chief is absent
stories.summary: Amid internal criticism and political pressure linked to President Trump's influence, D.C. Police Chief Pamela A. Smith faces challenges within the department as officers express concerns about leadership absence and departmental turmoil during a period of intense scrutiny.

stories.headline: On migration, Greece takes a Trumpian turn
stories.summary: Greece is intensifying its crackdown on unauthorized migrants by erecting high barriers and increasing patrols around detention centers, mirroring controversial U.S. immigration policies under President Trump, leading to human rights concerns and challenges faced by migrants.

stories.headline: Maxwell told DOJ Trump never acted improperly
stories.summary: Jeffrey Epstein's associate Ghislaine Maxwell reportedly told the Justice Department that she never observed former President Donald Trump engaging in inappropriate behavior, denying allegations of misconduct during an interview amid ongoing investigations.

stories.headline: Fed weighs rate cuts, citing a soft job market
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell indicated that a slow job market may justify future interest rate cuts but warned about the risks of inflation, emphasizing a cautious approach to policy adjustments amid rising economic uncertainty.

stories.headline: Powell opens door for rate cut
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has indicated the possibility of a September interest rate cut despite recent inflation increases, citing rising downside risks to employment. Powell announced a reversal of a previous 5-year policy shift that could lead to somewhat lower interest rates over the longer term. Investors reacted positively to the prospect of a rate cut at the Fed's upcoming September meeting, hopeful that this would reduce borrowing costs for consumers and ease pressures on credit markets.

stories.headline: Group says Gaza City is officially in famine
stories.summary: A global hunger monitor has officially declared Gaza City in famine, marking the first such assessment outside Africa. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification system reported that over 514,000 Palestinians in Gaza are experiencing famine due to ongoing conflict and worsening conditions. The report warns the situation could deteriorate further if no relief is provided, although the Israeli government has dismissed the report as biased. The classification of famine highlights the urgent humanitarian crisis in the region.

stories.headline: Henry Ford Hospital shooting leaves 1 dead
stories.summary: Detroit police are investigating a shooting incident at Henry Ford Hospital where a man, Mario Green, allegedly killed his ex-wife in the basement after an argument. Police are seeking public help in locating Green who reportedly entered the hospital premises with a firearm and shot his ex-wife multiple times. The hospital is back open to patients and visitors following the incident, and resources are being dedicated to support those affected.
people: Detroit Police Department Chief Todd Bettison

stories.headline: Harp Maker Decides to Stay at Longtime Near West Side Location
stories.summary: A local harp maker has decided to remain at its longtime location on the Near West Side, continuing its tradition and service to the community. The decision brings relief to customers and supports the area's cultural heritage.

stories.headline: National Archives Publishes Thousands of Emmett Till Documents Online
stories.summary: As the 70th anniversary of Emmett Till's murder approaches, the National Archives has released thousands of documents related to the case online, providing public access to historical records and shedding light on this pivotal event in civil rights history.

stories.headline: Trump: Chicago Will Be 'Next.' Mayor: That Would Be 'Unlawful.'
stories.summary: In a controversial statement, former President Trump declared that Chicago will be 'next' in a context not fully detailed here, prompting the Chicago mayor to respond that such an action would be unlawful. The story highlights the political tension and responses from city officials.

stories.headline: Remembering Ryno
stories.summary: Fans gathered outside Wrigley Field to watch the funeral service of Ryne Sandberg and pay tribute to the Cubs legend. Brian Grunst placed the jersey of his brother Gregory Grunst, who died from cancer last year, on a memorial to Sandberg outside Wrigley Field.

stories.headline: Candidates make their final pitch
stories.summary: Mayoral and City Council candidates for Decatur's 2025 municipal election had their final political forum to present their positions. Seventeen of twenty candidates participated in the forum hosted by various local women's and diversity groups. The forum did not include the District 1 school board race. Key mayoral candidates like Billy Jackson, who has served as a councilman for 29 years, and others expressed their plans and motivations for running. The election polls will be open on Tuesday from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.

stories.headline: Pryor Field gets ready for air show
stories.summary: Pryor Field Regional Airport is preparing for the North Alabama Airfest scheduled on Sept. 13-14, which is touted as the best weekend in Alabama. The event promises multiple military demonstrations, high-speed fly-bys, helicopter and airplane rides, exotic car rides, static displays, and vendor presence. Skip Stewart, a noted aerobatics pilot, will perform at the airshow. The festival aims to attract people from across the United States and emphasizes its unique blend of airshow entertainment and community gathering.

stories.headline: AI increasing energy demands
stories.summary: The Trump administration highlights the growth of artificial intelligence technologies and infrastructure similar to historical developments in the 1950s and 1960s, contributing to increased energy demands especially in north Alabama. TVA President and CEO Don Moul announced a landmark power purchase agreement between TVA, Google, and Kairos Power's Hermes 2 Plant to supply nuclear energy to the TVA grid, aiming to support Google's energy needs by 2035 with 500 megawatts of nuclear power in Montgomery County.

stories.headline: Agency: Gaza City gripped by famine, likely to spread
stories.summary: The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) announced that Gaza City is experiencing famine conditions likely to spread across the region. Restrictions on humanitarian aid and ongoing conflict have led to severe food shortages affecting hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, including children. Israel dismissed the report as untrue. The U.S. State Department expressed serious concern and highlighted the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the Middle East.

stories.headline: A Prairie Biome Companion
stories.summary: A new database catalogs plant species in Illinois' prairie restoration sites to help restore the state's natural landscape. Botanist Jim Jambon and a team manage one of the prairie restoration sites in Glencoe. The database aims to fill a gap in prairie knowledge and better understand the diversity of species, drawing comparisons to similar ecosystems in Australia. This research helps ensure prairie restorations are comprehensive and ecologically rich.

stories.headline: Despite warnings, fatal party went on
stories.summary: Jorge Sanchez encountered large crowds for a massive end-of-summer party in Austin despite warnings and a cancellation attempt by promoter Jamal Williams. The event resulted in eight people being shot, two of whom fatally, with police and public records confirming at least six others were wounded. The party, which was promoted by a suspended CPS aide, drew criticism for ignoring risks and warnings from authorities.

stories.headline: Trump poses Chicago takeover
stories.summary: President Donald Trump suggested Chicago would be the next location for a federal troop deployment similar to the one in Washington, D.C. Both Mayor Brandon Johnson and Gov. JB Pritzker called the suggestion illegal and authoritarian, warning it risks inflaming tensions and undermining trust between police and local communities. Pritzker emphasized that Chicagoans are not begging for a federal power grab and vowed to stand up for the city's sovereignty.

stories.headline: DeSantis to challenge order to end operations
stories.summary: U.S. District Judge Kathleen Williams ruled that Florida must stop taking in immigrant detainees at the Everglades detention center within 60 days. Gov. Ron DeSantis' administration plans to challenge the federal court ruling that would cease operations at the immigration detention camp known as Alligator Alcatraz in the Everglades. DeSantis called the government's position a "fair shake" and promised to respond accordingly. The detention center currently holds just under 400 detainees, and the ruling involves concerns over environmental and endangered species impacts at the site.

stories.headline: Fuchs: After Ono rejection, UF search ‘more challenging’
stories.summary: At the University of Florida's first faculty senate meeting of the school year, interim president Kent Fuchs said the search for a new president has become "more challenging" after rejection by candidate Santa Ono. Fuchs has extended his stay as interim president and emphasized the difficulty of finding a candidate with the leadership and academic excellence necessary. The UF Board of Trustees plans to discuss its leadership at a meeting next week. Fuchs acknowledged the challenges and expressed his appreciation for faculty concerns as they start the academic year.

stories.headline: After growth, immigrant population shrinks in 2025
stories.summary: For the first time in six decades, the number of immigrants living in the United States has dropped, according to a new Pew Research Center analysis. The immigrant population peaked at 53.3 million in January 2025 but fell to 51.8 million by June, the largest single-month decline ever recorded. The drop mirrors immigrant patterns seen during the Great Depression. The decline is tied to stricter immigration policies, fewer asylum requests, and reduced arrivals during President Biden's administration. The study highlights a notable decrease in new immigrants and increases in departures from the U.S.

stories.headline: Council asks mayor to study leaving Duke Energy
stories.summary: The St. Petersburg City Council voted to formally ask Mayor Ken Welch's administration to explore the feasibility of dropping Duke Energy as the city's electricity provider. The 5-3 vote marked the first time the council officially put this issue on record, after discussions on sustainability and energy sources. Some council members opposed the motion. The mayor, formerly an accountant for Duke Energy Florida, issued a memo agreeing to develop a plan and bid for consultants to conduct a feasibility study. This step aims to clarify perceived costs, benefits, and goals regarding energy providers.

stories.headline: Street art in St. Pete will be removed
stories.summary: Five street art installations in St. Petersburg will be painted over by the Florida Department of Transportation by September 4 unless an exemption is granted. The city requested an exemption, citing that the street art murals convey a strong sense of community and make roads safer. However, the request was denied, and the installations will be removed. The city transportation and parking management director stated that the removal would happen at the city's expense, but the city remains committed to lawful ways to celebrate and express community values.

stories.headline: Ukrainian marine’s journey highlights hidden toll of war
stories.summary: Yurii Saiko, a Ukrainian marine wounded during the war in Mariupol, describes the harrowing experiences of being injured, undergoing surgery, and surviving shelling and hospital attacks. Despite severe injuries and dangerous conditions, Saiko's story sheds light on the human cost of the conflict, including the impact on families and the resilience required to endure the ongoing war.

stories.headline: How funding will help Southern Tier counties
stories.summary: Three Southern Tier counties in New York will receive Youth Employment Program funding totaling $40.6 million, aimed at reducing community gun violence via employment and training opportunities for at-risk youth. The funding, announced by Gov. Kathy Hochul, will be distributed among Broome, Chemung, and Tompkins counties to support local programs including work and training opportunities for young people involved in the Gun Violence Elimination (GIVE) initiative.

stories.headline: There's So Much to Love About the NY State Fair
stories.summary: August brings bittersweet reminders that summer will soon end, but for those near Syracuse, the Great New York State Fair offers a seasonal tradition filled with foods, drinks, and festive activities. The fairground's legacy dates back 184 years and draws visitors with unique experiences including new transit options and various entertainment.

stories.headline: Canada lifts tariffs on most imports from Maine under trade pact with US, Mexico
stories.summary: Canada has dropped retaliatory tariffs on most U.S. goods, including imports from Maine, as part of the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement. Prime Minister Mark Carney and President Donald Trump agreed that the tariff exemptions would reset trade talks and reduce trade tensions, benefiting affected industries and consumers.

stories.headline: Businesses wary as $20 minimum wage awaits council vote
stories.summary: Portland business owners express opposition to a city council proposal to raise the minimum wage to $20 an hour by 2029, with an incremental increase starting in 2026. Proponents argue the increase is necessary to keep pace with living costs, but opponents fear it may lead to layoffs or business closures. City councilors plan to vote on whether to put the wage increase proposal on the November ballot.

stories.headline: Maine Med facing bat problem in neonatal intensive care unit
stories.summary: MaineHealth Maine Medical Center in Portland has struggled for several years to keep bats out of its neonatal intensive care unit, leading to an OSHA complaint last year. Despite efforts including replacing the Coulombe Family Tower facade, bats continue to enter the hospital. An OSHA complaint filed in June 2024 has since been resolved with no fines but an accepted action plan by MaineHealth.

stories.headline: The former Children’s Museum soon will be torn down. What comes next?
stories.summary: The city of Portland has approved a demolition permit for the former Children’s Museum at 142 Free Street. The site will become the centerpiece of the Portland Museum of Art’s $100 million expansion. In the meantime, there are calls for the area to be a public space for art and events as the Portland Museum of Art plans to replace the old building with a new wing.

stories.headline: Epstein’s ex denied witnessing Trump act inappropriately
stories.summary: Jeffrey Epstein's imprisoned former girlfriend repeatedly denied to the Justice Department that she saw Donald Trump engage in inappropriate sexual conduct. Released transcripts from interviews with Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche reveal that Ghislaine Maxwell has consistently denied knowledge of or witnessing such acts. The Trump administration has released the transcripts amid increased scrutiny and investigations related to the Epstein case.

stories.headline: TVA can OK incentive pay despite vacancies
stories.summary: The Tennessee Valley Authority's annual performance-based incentive pay checks can proceed even with empty seats on its board of directors. The TVA paid a record $276 million in performance bonuses last year with a median payout of $10,332. Although vacancies left the board with fewer than five members, recent rules and past actions show incentives can be approved without a quorum of directors. The utility, which funds its own operations, continues efforts to ensure electricity supply and comply with legal and regulatory requirements.

stories.headline: Former Trump adviser raided by FBI
stories.summary: FBI agents searched the home and office of John Bolton, former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, investigating whether he collected or leaked sensitive national security information. The raid represents a significant escalation in a long-running inquiry amid concerns about government agencies potentially using criminal justice machinery to pursue perceived enemies. The search required special judicial approval because it spanned two federal districts.

stories.headline: Officials declare famine in and around Gaza City
stories.summary: A global group of experts announced that Gaza City and its surrounding territory are officially suffering from famine nearly two years into an ongoing conflict. Israel's blockade of food and aid has caused severe hunger and malnutrition, with at least a million people facing starvation. The situation is expected to worsen, with two additional governorates projected to enter official famine by the end of September, according to a report by the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification.

stories.headline: Ex-Sonics star Shawn Kemp avoids jail time in '23 shooting
stories.summary: Former Seattle SuperSonics player Shawn Kemp was sentenced to 30 days of electronic home monitoring and community service after pleading guilty to a shooting incident inside a Tacoma Mall in March 2023. Kemp avoided jail time as he complied with court directives including home monitoring and community service.

stories.headline: Transcripts of Ghislaine Maxwell interviews released
stories.summary: Newly released transcripts from interviews with Ghislaine Maxwell reveal her denial of inappropriate interactions with Donald Trump, despite claims and accusations. The Justice Department resisted disclosing these transcripts, but their release provides insight into the inquiry surrounding Jeffrey Epstein and the Trump administration's reaction to the investigation.

stories.headline: Global food crisis monitor says parts of Gaza suffer from famine
stories.summary: Gaza City and surrounding areas are officially suffering from famine due to prolonged conflict and blockades, according to a global food crisis monitor. United Nations aid agencies are working to monitor and classify the severe hunger crisis facing the region, where conditions are worsening with starvation, acute malnutrition, and death increasingly common among the population.

stories.headline: FBI raids home of ex-Trump adviser
stories.summary: The FBI conducted searches at the Maryland home and Washington D.C. office of former Trump national security adviser John Bolton, as part of a criminal investigation into the mishandling of classified information. Bolton, who had been an outspoken critic of Donald Trump after his firing, has not been charged with any crimes and is cooperating with investigators.

stories.headline: What's driven thousands of farmers in state to shut down
stories.summary: Thousands of farmers in Washington state are shutting down due to multiple stressors including inflation, weather changes, and tariffs, causing many to leave the farming profession. This trend is driven by financial pressures and mental health challenges, with a 2025 report highlighting that the suicide rate among farmers far exceeds the national average.

stories.headline: Their American Dream Became a Mexican Nightmare
stories.summary: A family’s journey to the U.S. border took a tragic turn as they tried to evade crackdown on immigration promised by President Trump. The Aria family fled toward the U.S. border from Mexico to escape hardship but were caught in a dangerous situation involving ransoms and violence. The story highlights the human cost of immigration policy and enforcement in the region.

stories.headline: Powell Raises Hopes of a Rate Cut
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated a possible rate cut next month when he said the labor market might be softening enough to rein in inflation. Powell addressed economic risks, noting the balance of risks appears to be shifting, and hinted that payroll gains might slow this month. As a result, U.S. stocks surged with the Dow rising 1.9% to a record high, amid expectations the Fed might soon ease monetary policy.

stories.headline: President Says U.S. Will Take Big Stake In Intel
stories.summary: The U.S. government announced it is taking a 10% stake in troubled chipmaker Intel through a $8.9 billion deal. This government intervention aims to stabilize Intel amid the ongoing global chip shortage and behind-the-scenes negotiations. The president's move follows a two-week frenzy of talks and marks a significant step to protect the domestic semiconductor industry and strengthen chip manufacturing in the U.S.

stories.headline: FBI's Raid of Bolton Steps Up Probe Into a Key Trump Critic
stories.summary: The FBI raided the Maryland home and Washington, D.C. office of former Trump national security adviser John Bolton, escalating a years-old probe related to his role in revealing classified information from Trump's administration. The raid was part of a broader investigation into the unlawful disclosure of classified information that has become a politically charged issue under President Trump. The Justice Department and FBI are pursuing this case amid tension and political debate about national security and leaks.

stories.headline: F.B.I. Agents Search Bolton's Home
stories.summary: FBI agents searched the home and office of John R. Bolton, former national security adviser to President Trump, as part of a major escalation of an inquiry into whether he collected or leaked sensitive national security information. The investigation focuses on Bolton's handling of classified files, with agents scrutinizing his involvement in sharing sensitive documents post-administration. The probe highlights concerns about the enforcement of laws protecting classified information and spans different federal districts.

stories.headline: Monitors Report Gaza City Is Officially Under Famine
stories.summary: Gaza City and the surrounding territory are officially suffering from famine due to a complex combination of conflict, stringent Israeli restrictions, collapse of health care, water and sanitation systems, and destruction of local agriculture. The United Nations and aid agencies report that at least half a million people in Gaza face starvation, malnutrition, and death. The situation is described as "entirely man-made" and worsening, with expectations of escalation into an official famine by the end of September.

stories.headline: Powell Hints Fed Plans Rate Cuts
stories.summary: Jerome H. Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, indicated the possibility of rate cuts as economic data shows signs of weakening. Powell's recent speech suggested a reduction in borrowing costs might come after the Fed's next meeting in September, aiming to sustain economic growth and respond to labor market data and inflation trends. However, Powell stressed the need to proceed cautiously given uncertainties about economic strength and supply chain conditions.

stories.headline: Critic of Many U.S. Colleges Sees a Need to Defend Them
stories.summary: The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, a civil rights group focused on free speech, highlights the challenges U.S. colleges face regarding free speech and political correctness. The group warns of increased government efforts to deport politically targeted students and defends the need for open campuses. The discussion includes concerns over political bias and repression witnessed by some supporters and a call for vigilance in protecting free expression on campuses.

stories.headline: Republicans Counter I.V.F. With 'Natural' Plan
stories.summary: Facing a political backlash, Alabama Senate Republicans proposed a new plan aiming to sway supporters of in vitro fertilization with an emphasis on a once-fringe infertility method. The approach is targeted at influencing popular conservatives, including allies of former President Donald J. Trump, by promoting a 'natural' infertility treatment alternative. The strategy is part of a larger conservative effort to reshape abortion and fertility-related debates and reflects ongoing cultural policy battles.

stories.headline: New York City Corruption's Fall From Grandeur
stories.summary: A detailed report reveals the ongoing corruption scandal in New York City involving influential figures such as a former mayor and his adviser. The investigation exposes bribery, political favors, and a growing corruption ring, particularly highlighting a businessman with ties to political payoffs and illegal activities. Authorities are pursuing indictments against those involved, showing how deeply corruption has infiltrated city politics and business networks.

stories.headline: Five Dead in Crash
stories.summary: A bus traveling from Niagara Falls, New York, to New York City crashed east of Buffalo on Friday, resulting in five fatalities and ejecting some passengers. The accident highlights ongoing concerns about road safety and the need for improved transportation regulations.

stories.headline: Abrego Garcia released from Tenn. jail
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Maryland man wrongfully detained in Tennessee due to mistaken deportation, was released and reportedly headed back to Maryland. Born in El Salvador and a Prince George's County resident, Garcia's case highlighted immigration enforcement issues and led to a federal judicial order ensuring his travel back home. The Maryland community and his attorney thanked the courts for the resolution.

stories.headline: Russia’s top diplomat: No plans made for summit
stories.summary: Russia's top diplomat confirmed that no meetings have been scheduled between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss the ongoing conflict or the proposed three-year war plan. This announcement underscores continuing tensions and uncertainty in diplomatic efforts toward peace.

stories.headline: Food crises authority announces famine in Gaza
stories.summary: The world's leading authority on food crises officially declared a famine in Gaza, warning that continued conflict and blockade conditions threaten massive humanitarian disaster. Relief efforts face severe challenges amid rising violence and restrictions on aid access, escalating international concern.

stories.headline: Freedom Caucus: Moore ‘used street language’
stories.summary: Maryland Freedom Caucus leader calls out Delegate Wes Moore for using colloquial language during a public statement, asserting it was not racist but that some listeners misinterpreted it. The exchange reflects ongoing political rhetoric and cultural tensions within state politics.

stories.headline: Tariff impact
stories.summary: The Trump administration removed a new Congressional Budget Office update that projected tariffs would lower deficits, replacing it with information that tariffs reduced deficits by less than previously thought. The updated outlook forecasts a combined $4 trillion increase over ten years instead of reductions. This revision influences budget debates and trade policy discussions.

stories.headline: Defense firing
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth fired a general after a negative intelligence assessment related to Iranian nuclear activities strained U.S. relations. The decision reflects ongoing tensions within the Defense Intelligence Agency over personnel and policy. The move was not made public but reported by insiders.

stories.headline: Epstein’s former girlfriend: Trump did not act in ‘inappropriate way’
stories.summary: Jeffrey Epstein's imprisoned former girlfriend denied allegations of sexually inappropriate behavior by Donald Trump, presenting records that show Trump was praised during their questioning. These disclosures aim to distance Trump from the disgraced financier and dismiss claims against him. The Trump administration released many pages of transcripts to clarify the matter.

stories.headline: State could see influx of homeless from DC that would strain shelters
stories.summary: The Kennedy Center homeless encampment near Washington, D.C. was cleared on August 14, displacing dozens. This move may lead to more homeless individuals moving into Maryland, potentially overwhelming shelters in Montgomery County and other parts of the state. Local officials are concerned about capacity and the long-term impact on homelessness services.

stories.headline: Ocean City rental restrictions, beach tents, wind turbines
stories.summary: Ocean City Mayor Richard Meehan discussed the town's stance on rental regulations, beach tent policies, and wind turbine developments amid rising visitor numbers. While voters opposed short-term rental bans in certain neighborhoods, local government aims to balance tourism with residential quality of life. Interview highlights the challenges of managing a popular summer destination.

stories.headline: Trump blasts Baltimore, cities over crime
stories.summary: President Donald Trump criticized Baltimore and other major cities for their crime rates, calling for federal intervention and greater law enforcement deployment. Though some city leaders scoffed at his comments, the debate over federal versus local control of crime prevention continues. Reactions vary widely, with some community voices stressing the need for comprehensive solutions.

stories.headline: Mountain town getaway
stories.summary: The story highlights top attractions in Williams, including the Grand Canyon Railway, Bearizona, and Route 66 neon, perfect for a tucked-away mountain town getaway.

stories.headline: Storms slam valley
stories.summary: Heavy storms caused flooding on 64th Street in Scottsdale, as pictured by a man walking past a downed tree on August 21.

stories.headline: Fateful ad leads to career
stories.summary: Jason Mohns, initially unplanned to pursue coaching football, was inspired by a newspaper ad to join the Arizona State University football team, where he is now the tight ends coach.

stories.headline: Prosecutors could testify in Palestinian protesters case
stories.summary: Pro-Palestinian protesters have cleared a legal obstacle against Maricopa County Attorney Rachel Mitchell's prosecution efforts, with university court agreeing there is enough proof that county prosecutors were retaliatory or overly suppressive. A hearing in late November will determine if prosecutors can testify to support their case. Protesters' attorneys planned to subpoena the county attorney and other prosecutors involved.

stories.headline: Immigrant activists, court security clash on rights cards
stories.summary: Immigration activists were prevented from distributing "know your rights" cards at a building leased for immigration court due to a private security firm's enforcement of a "No Handbills" policy. The Phoenix Police Department later upheld the activists' right to distribute the cards inside the courthouse's third floor. Activists also observed immigration proceedings to inform people of their rights, sparking questions about public access rights and First Amendment protections at government courtrooms located in private buildings.

stories.headline: Trump, GOP are on verge of win in Texas
stories.summary: A partisan battle in Texas over congressional district redistricting is unfolding, with Republican Gov. Greg Abbott and allies, including President Donald Trump, aiming to gain a strategic advantage ahead of the 2026 elections. The fight reaches beyond Texas' borders, involving key state leaders such as California Gov. Gavin Newsom, who are reshaping district boundaries as Republicans seek to redraw districts inside their states.

stories.headline: UH, HCC restart faculty senates amid questions on representation
stories.summary: Houston City College and the University of Houston System have revamped their faculty advisory groups to comply with a Republican-fueled law affecting their roles and temporarily dissolved senates. The institutions are restructuring to meet new regulations, including abolishing existing Faculty Senates and replacing them with groups that follow new rules. Both Houston and Texas State University systems have seen shifts in faculty governance amid this legislative change, with university leadership guided by legal compliance considerations.

stories.headline: 3 accused of altering water test results at Conroe lab
stories.summary: Two former employees of a wastewater testing lab in Conroe face federal conspiracy charges after allegedly falsifying test results to conceal illegal pollutant levels in local waterways. The accusations involve tampering with environmental compliance reports over three years, potentially putting public water safety at risk. State wastewater treatment professional associations express concern over industry malfeasance, while lawyers for the accused did not respond to comment requests.

stories.headline: Wu takes on spotlight to lead Texas Dems
stories.summary: State Representative Gene Wu has become the prominent face of the Texas Democrats' battle to defeat President Donald Trump's congressional redistricting plan. Wu confronts cultural norms and battles racism as he advocates for the party's cause, speaking out on national TV and preparing appearances to marshal party support. Despite being an introvert, Wu embraces his leadership role and the challenges that come with it, representing the state's Democrats in a crucial political fight.

stories.headline: House bill targets pills for abortion
stories.summary: Texas Republicans are intensifying efforts to crack down on abortion pills by proposing a House bill that sets federal commerce protections aside and allows private citizens to sue out-of-state abortion pill prescribers and manufacturers. The bill is part of a larger Republican effort to stop the flow of abortion pills into Texas, continuing despite a near-total ban on the procedure. The legislation includes provisions to shift enforcement tactics and could result in private lawsuits against those supplying abortion pills to Texas residents.

stories.headline: DeSantis defends 'Alligator Alcatraz'
stories.summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis defended his decision to establish an immigration detention center in the Everglades, nicknamed 'Alligator Alcatraz,' in response to a federal judge's order to shut it down. DeSantis vowed to fight the order but did not address the judge's concerns about the facility violating environmental laws. The ongoing legal battle highlights tension between state and federal authorities over immigration enforcement and environmental protections.

stories.headline: FBI searches home of ex-Trump national security adviser
stories.summary: The FBI conducted a search of the home and office of John Bolton, former national security adviser to Donald Trump, as part of an investigation into the handling of classified materials. Bolton, a vocal critic of Trump, has stated he is a 'real, sort of a lowlife' target in the probe but emphasized his cooperation with authorities. The search relates to allegations that Bolton took sensitive documents following his government service, raising significant legal and political implications.

stories.headline: Closed Minnesota prison on ICE list
stories.summary: Minnesota's only privately owned prison, the shuttered Prairie Correctional Facility in Appleton, is now on an internal ICE list of potential sites for immigrant detention space. CoreCivic, which owns the facility, has called for reopening and operating the site as a 600-bed detention center. The listing responds to a potential increase in demand for immigrant detention facilities by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, sparking debate on usage and local impact.

stories.headline: Mpls. fight threatens wider DFL split
stories.summary: The Minnesota DFL's decision to revoke the endorsement of mayoral candidate Omar Fateh has sparked a significant rift within the party, pitting progressives against moderates. The clash highlights deeper tensions between the party's establishment and more progressive members, with potential impacts on upcoming elections and party unity as representatives of labor unions and progressive groups denounce the decision.

stories.headline: North of Minnesota, vast Canadian wildfires take serious human toll
stories.summary: Wildfires in northern Minnesota and across vast regions of Canada, particularly in Manitoba, have caused significant destruction and loss of life. Volunteer firefighters, like Ken Lachnit, worked tirelessly to combat the fast-spreading fires that devastated homes and landscapes. The smoke from these fires has been identified as evidence of Manitoba's worst fire season in three decades, affecting communities downwind and raising serious concerns about wildfire management and impact.

stories.headline: Dugan gave account of incident days before arrest
stories.summary: Milwaukee County Judge Hannah Dugan provided an account of events leading up to her arrest days after federal agents detained an undocumented immigrant who appeared in her courtroom. Police bodycam footage captured Dugan's remarks disputing accusations against her and addressing concerns about threats prior to her arrest on charges of obstructing a federal agency and concealing a wanted person.

stories.headline: FEMA visit is next step toward disaster ruling
stories.summary: Following severe flooding in a Milwaukee neighborhood, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) along with the Wisconsin Emergency Management and Milwaukee County officials conducted damage assessments and interviews with affected residents. The visit aims to determine eligibility for federal disaster relief and aid in the recovery process.
people: Milwaukee County Office of Emergency Management

stories.headline: Uecker leaves hole in Wisconsin summer
stories.summary: Bob Uecker's distinctive voice and presence have been a memorable part of Milwaukee Brewers baseball for over 40 years. The story reflects on his role as the team's play-by-play announcer, his connection to fans across generations, and the enduring impact he has had on the Milwaukee baseball community.

stories.headline: Family blames IMPD detectives, prosecutors
stories.summary: The family of Jon Edwards, who fatally shot in 2021, expressed frustration after his mother's murder case was dismissed post-jury verdict. The woman previously accused and standing trial for the killing was acquitted, leading the family to fault the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department detectives and prosecutors for their handling of the case. The case remains a source of distress, especially for Edwards' father who has since started a trucking business.

stories.headline: Michigan City prison to stay open past 2027
stories.summary: The Indiana Department of Correction is reversing earlier plans to close the Indiana State Prison in Michigan City upon opening a new $1.2 billion facility in 2027. Instead, state corrections officials will keep the aging prison operational for an unspecified time to address staffing and operational concerns. This shift alters the 2023 consolidation plan to shutter both Michigan City and Westville correctional facilities to reduce costs.

stories.headline: IndyGo board OKs 57% fare increase
stories.summary: The IndyGo transit agency board approved a 57% fare increase for bus rides starting January 1, 2026, with fares rising from $1.75 to $2.75 for a typical bus trip. The board also authorized a 2026 budget increase to $90 million to support ongoing construction projects like the Blue Line. The fare hike is intended to offset rising costs and maintain service levels amid challenges like lower ridership. Reduced discounts for certain riders will also change effective July 1, 2026.

stories.headline: Fed's Powell opens door for rate cut
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated on August 22 that a September interest rate cut remains possible despite recent inflation concerns. He highlighted rising downside risks to employment and a potential economic slowdown, which could justify lowering rates. Powell revealed a possible reversal of a recent 5-year-old policy, suggesting the Fed may reduce borrowing costs to support the economy and mitigate rising unemployment and credit risks.

stories.headline: Dems propose law to fight National Guard deployments
stories.summary: Democrats in the Michigan House introduced a bill to require state permission before President Trump can send National Guard troops to Michigan for military duty without the state governor's consent. The bill aims to prevent any unauthorized deployments of the National Guard in Michigan and challenges federal authority in such cases. The bill is a response to President Trump's deployment of troops to cities for immigration-related missions, which has faced criticism and legal challenges.

stories.headline: 'Band-Aid' fix planned for interchange in need of rebuild
stories.summary: Michigan is planning to put a $5.5 million 'Band-Aid' on a busy highway interchange in Flint, at I-75/I-69, highlighting the state's infrastructure funding crisis. The interchange, used by over 30,000 vehicles daily, needs a complete rebuild due to declining road and bridge conditions and increased traffic, with a full rebuild costing an estimated $1.3 billion. Without increased funding, Michigan Department of Transportation warns up to 200 highway bridges could close by 2035. The state senate has not yet addressed the House-passed infrastructure bill.

stories.headline: Where's the beef? Prices are way up.
stories.summary: Experts say consumers shouldn't expect much relief anytime soon as beef prices have been steadily rising over the past 20 years due to supply and demand factors, drought conditions, a flesh-eating pest affecting cattle, and tariffs impacting supply. Ground beef prices reached record highs with an average price of $6.12 per pound in June, nearly 12% up from last year, with prices for all uncooked beef steaks also rising. The high prices may lead shoppers to buy less hamburger meat and fewer steaks.

stories.headline: Measure targets pills for abortion
stories.summary: Texas Republicans are intensifying efforts to crack down on abortion pills by targeting out-of-state providers and manufacturers through proposed legislation. House Bill 7 aims to empower private citizens to sue prescribers and distributors for violations, with penalties including fines and manufacturing bans. The bill is part of a broader GOP strategy to restrict access to abortion pills in Texas, despite criticism from advocacy groups about its impact on safety and personal freedoms.

stories.headline: Democrats who left state each fined over $9,000
stories.summary: Texas House Democrats who broke quorum to block GOP redistricting have been fined more than $9,000 each, with total fines exceeding $47,000. The fines were issued by the House Administration Committee, requiring payment before Democrats can return or seek re-election. The Democratic Caucus confirmed all members who left received fines, with a deadline given to pay or notify plans to do so. The move reflects ongoing tensions over redistricting efforts.

stories.headline: State senator plans filibuster of map vote
stories.summary: State Senator Carol Alvarado of Houston intends to filibuster Republicans' redistricting map as a last effort to delay its passage and preserve Democratic seats. Despite her plans to hold the Senate floor as long as possible, the move is seen as unlikely to prevent the bill from reaching Governor Abbott's desk. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and other Republican leaders are expected to push the vote through, continuing the redistricting process.

stories.headline: Doggett warns of exit from House
stories.summary: Congressman Lloyd Doggett announced he will end his 52-year political career and not challenge Casar if the GOP redistricting plan is upheld in court. Doggett, 78, expressed concerns about a heavily redrawn congressional map favoring Trump allies, warning of a potentially costly primary showdown. He said the new map cuts into the liberal voter base and contains more than two-thirds of his current constituents but is prepared to step aside to avoid divisive battles.

stories.headline: Blaze nears wineries, forces evacuations
stories.summary: A fast-moving wildfire near Calistoga grew to more than 2,100 acres on Friday, threatening several Napa Valley wineries and prompting evacuation orders in rural parts of the county. The Pickett Fire spread rapidly in hot, dry conditions, and crews worked to contain the flames. The fire, which started before 3 p.m. Thursday, was 5% contained by Friday afternoon. Cal Fire stated the cause remained under investigation, with evacuation orders and warnings in place for several areas.

stories.headline: Prosecutors refile murder charges after high court tosses conviction
stories.summary: A 31-year-old man who was sentenced to life in prison for the killing of a Santa Fe homeowner is facing a revised first-degree murder charge after the State Supreme Court overturned the previous conviction. The case involves evidence and legal proceedings addressing issues related to the original sentencing and new charges being filed.

stories.headline: Takin’ pride by the horns
stories.summary: The 33rd annual Zia Regional Rodeo held at the Santa Fe Rodeo Grounds celebrates equality, resilience, and competition within the LGBTQ+ community. Events include traditional rodeo activities along with performances from cowboy hats to modern-day rodeo circuit challenges. The event fosters community engagement and pride through various rodeo competitions and activities.

stories.headline: Webber floats $2.50 increase to living wage in S.F. by 2027
stories.summary: Santa Fe Mayor Alan Webber proposed a gradual increase in the city's living wage to $17.50 per hour, adding $2.50 to the current wage by early 2027. The proposal is in early stages and includes seeking input from workers, business leaders, and constituents, with a key focus on inclusive discussion and participation from all voices.

stories.headline: Overdoses on rise in run-up to order
stories.summary: A new state emergency declaration promises more funding for police in the Española Valley due to a crisis tied to addictive drugs. Although no plans have been discussed for deploying the National Guard, the Governor's office is focusing on spending $750,000 in state funding for law enforcement to address rising overdoses and violent crime related to drug trafficking and public safety threats.

stories.headline: Festival celebrates food, music and new citizens
stories.summary: The World Food & Music Festival kicked off on August 22 with a naturalization ceremony for 50 new U.S. citizens. The festival continues through August 24 with more than 60 vendors offering international cuisine and two stages featuring music, spoken word, and dance from around the world.

stories.headline: DMPS students get new principals, cell phone rules
stories.summary: Des Moines Public Schools is implementing new principals, expanded business offices, policies, and partnerships as students return to class. The district will begin portions of its Reimagining Education plan, including a program aimed at preparing students for life after high school. Additionally, a bond for a new school and facility improvements will be put to public vote in November.

stories.headline: Americana restaurant closing in September
stories.summary: Americana, a landmark brunch restaurant in Des Moines' Western Gateway, is closing after 14 years. The announcement thanked guests and staff for their support, highlighting the restaurant's role in creating memorable experiences. Americana is part of a group owned by Scott Carlson, who recently sold his share to concentrate on other ventures.

stories.headline: Famine declared as Israel plans assault
stories.summary: A severe food crisis has been declared in Gaza City following the latest round of conflict and siege by Israel. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification reports a hunger emergency with hundreds of thousands affected. The anticipated Israeli assault and restricted access to humanitarian aid exacerbate the situation. The declaration comes after months of warnings by aid groups.

stories.headline: Governors send Guard, along with a measure of devotion
stories.summary: Several Republican governors, under pressure from President Trump, have agreed to deploy National Guard troops to Washington D.C. to support security efforts amid political tensions. This demonstrates loyalty to Trump and is part of a broader political initiative. The move is notable given the concerns about the impact on public resources and political optics.

stories.headline: As challenges rise, hospital reveals layoffs
stories.summary: South Shore Health announced layoffs of 51 employees and expects further job cuts due to escalating costs and reductions in federal funding. Other Massachusetts hospitals, including UMass Memorial Health, are also reducing staff in anticipation of budget cuts. Overall, hospital systems are struggling with a competitive labor market and reduced resources.

stories.headline: For some, attending classes is lower priority
stories.summary: At Harvard University, some undergraduates are prioritizing extracurricular activities over attending classes, contributing to a viewpoint diversity debate. Harvard students spend significant time on extracurriculars, and professors feel that this affects learning. Harvard's dean noted that attendance and engagement have declined, with some students favoring trendy ideas and causes more than academic discourse.

stories.headline: Powell signals interest rate cut
stories.summary: Jerome Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, indicated in a closely watched speech that the central bank is preparing to begin interest rate cuts soon due to concerns about a slowing job market. However, inflation remains stubborn. Powell highlighted economic risks and suggested a rate cut might be appropriate at the September meeting, citing a balance of risks and slower job growth.

stories.headline: FBI searches home of ex-Trump official Bolton
stories.summary: The FBI conducted a search at the home of former national security adviser John Bolton on August 22, authorized by court order. This action, criticized by some as excessive, came as part of investigations into classified information and other matters related to the previous administration's activities. Bolton has publicly criticized the administration and denied wrongdoing.

stories.headline: Trafficking fliers being considered in schools
stories.summary: The Palm Beach County School District is considering distributing flier materials in middle and high schools to raise awareness about human trafficking, especially linked to the case of Jeffrey Epstein. Many of Epstein's victims were recruited from local schools. The initiative aims to protect students by educating them on the dangers of trafficking and providing resources for help.

stories.headline: Federal judge says Trump must wind down 'Alcatraz'
stories.summary: A federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to halt construction and begin dismantling mass detention centers, specifically the 'Alcatraz' immigration facility in the Everglades National Preserve. The ruling aims to protect the environment and prevent further infrastructure development at the site. Environmental and indigenous leaders have welcomed this decision as a victory for conservation and human rights.

stories.headline: FPL proposes a new plan for rate increases
stories.summary: Florida Power & Light (FPL) has proposed a new four-year rate schedule that includes a typical monthly bill increase of nearly $4 starting in 2026. The plan aims to reduce the rate hikes initially requested, with an emphasis on keeping residential customer bills below projected averages through 2030. FPL's proposal represents a slower growth in electricity costs compared to previous years, despite some criticism from consumer advocates.

stories.headline: Bullet was meant for dealers, feds say
stories.summary: Authorities reveal new information about a fatal incident involving a 16-year-old hockey player who was struck by gunfire while riding in an SUV on I-55. Federal court records indicate that the bullet aimed at drug dealers strayed and hit the youth, sparking regional grief and police investigation. Documents disclosed detail a wider drug distribution case and ongoing probes involving firearms and narcotics in the area.

stories.headline: Imo’s employee apologizes for stabbing homeless man
stories.summary: An employee of Imo's in Clayton apologized publicly after stabbing a homeless man at a local pizzeria. The employee claimed self-defense but acknowledged wrongdoing. He is currently out on house arrest awaiting trial for assault charges. The judge has set a bond hearing for the accused later, showing legal proceedings are underway.

stories.headline: Former area student sues district, former principal
stories.summary: A Clayton former student has filed a lawsuit against the school district and a former principal for ignoring reports of sexual abuse by an ex-high school leader. The lawsuit alleges the defendants solicited inappropriate images and videos and failed to intervene appropriately, with the plaintiff having been abused since 2020. The case spotlights allegations of institutional neglect and ongoing legal actions.

stories.headline: Negotiations set to resume
stories.summary: Boeing workers' strike continues into its third week with formal talks set to restart Monday. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and Boeing confirmed that representatives will meet to negotiate in hopes of ending the strike and bringing workers back to their jobs. Key union leaders and Congress members have expressed support and pressure for a resolution.
